awd_abstract_narration:
Electrons have the fundamental property of "spin," which is analogous to that of a spinning toy top, and is associated with their angular momentum. This project studies collisions between polarized electrons, which have their spins aligned in one direction, and chiral, or "handed" molecules.  Such molecules, of which DNA is an example, are characterized by a spiral, or helical geometry. These experiments address physics questions about the dynamics of electron-chiral molecule scattering, particularly with regard to the role played by the electron spins.  They will also provide important clues about the origins of biological homochirality - the fact that all naturally-occurring DNA spirals in the same direction.  Atoms of zinc are also being used as targets, to check the results of an experiment done recently by another group in which zinc atoms excited by polarized electrons emitted light in a way that is forbidden by all known theories of atomic collisions.  If that result is reproduced, much of the basic theoretical knowledge about spin-polarized electron-impact-excitation physics would need to be revised. Improved sources of polarized electrons are also being developed in  this project, with the goal of making "turnkey" components that will be easily integrated into other experimental systems.  Two particular ways to make polarized electrons are being investigated in this project. The first involves electron collisions with rubidium atoms in which spin is transferred from the rubidium to the free electrons. The second uses multiphoton ionization of semiconductors such as gallium arsenide (GaAs) to give the electrons a preferential spin direction. This research to develop polarized electron technology holds the promise of providing new analytical tools that can be used for biological and materials research, and for industry. 

Experiments involving collisions between polarized electrons and chiral molecules will extend previous work that showed chiral sensitivity in both quasi-elastic and reactive scattering with halocamphor targets.  Now that such sensitivity has been observed, the goal is to demonstrate such effects in molecules that have biological significance, such as cysteine, and to study the effect of the maximum target nuclear charge and location of the target's chiral center on the chiral asymmetries we observe.  The goal in the Zn experiments is to check whether the rather large value of canted linear polarization (polarization fraction P2) observed in fluorescence from excited Zn atoms is reproducible.  No extant theory of electron-atom scattering, including the state-of-the-art "R-matrix with pseudostates" approach, has been able to confirm this result, even though they make quantitatively accurate predictions of other collision parameters for this system. Source development work will be based on the successfully demonstrated "Rb spin-filter" design by the group, in which optically-pumped Rb undergoes spin-exchange collisions with an incident unpolarized beam of electrons.  This project will focus on improving the vacuum system, the Rb target reliability, and the optical pumping protocol.  It will also study a variety of buffer gases to understand the complex physics of the interaction between the electron beam and the Rb vapor.  In the GaAs experiment, unamplified pulses from a femtosecond Ti:Saph oscillator are used to photo-emit electrons. First experiments will investigate the intensity and polarization of the electrons emitted from bulk GaAs and tip-like GaAs shards.  Then targets of GaAs cusp arrays will be considered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported experiments that study the role of chirality in physics. "Chirality," derived from the Greek word χειρ, meaning "hand," is associated with any object or process that has two forms - a right-handed form and a left handed form that are mirror images of each other. Two good examples of chiral objects are, of course, left and right hands, or a football in a tight spiral pass (Figure 1). If the ball is moving toward a receiver, they will see a "right-handed" football rotating counter clockwise, while a left-handed football will rotate clockwise.

This project has studied how chirality can play a role when electrons scatter from molecules that are themselves chiral.  Electrons can be right or left-handed like spinning footballs, and molecules with mirror images that are distinguishable are also chiral (Figure 2).  In the same way that a right-handed nut can't screw onto a left handed bollt, we expect right- and left-handed electrons will scatter differently from, e.g., a right-handed molecule.

The experiments supported by this award have studied such collisions in two different ways. First, we studied chemical reactions in which an incident electron breaks apart a target halocamphor molecule, like those shown in Figure 2. The reaction is e- + BA → B- + A. Like the nut/bolt analogy, one expects that at some microscopic level, there may be a difference in the chemical reaction rates depending on the relative chirality of the target molecule and the incident electron.  Such effects have been observed; they are small but measurable.  The science question is: what's the electromagnetic mechanism whereby the molecule can distinguish electrons that are right-handed from those that are left-handed? Experiments so far indicate that the electric charge of the heaviest atom in the molecule plays an important role, but the role this charge plays remains ambiguous.  By varying the Z of the heaviest atom in our target molecules and by moving this atom to different locations (Figure 2), we hope to gain further insight into the physics of the scattering process.

These is another reason why such a breakup reaction is interesting. The fact that all naturally occurring DNA is right-handed is a mystery, since most scientists think that on the early earth, when the precursors of molecules in living cells were just beginning to form, the chemical interactions responsible for producing them must have created equal amounts of right- and left-handed molecules. If this is true, where did all the left-handed DNA go?  One possible answer is suggested by the "Vester-Ulbricht" hypothesis, that says that chiral electrons in cosmic rays, that are predominantly left handed, preferentially detroyed the nascent left-handed DNA, leaving only the right-handed species to create life (Figure 3). Experiments supported by this award have shown that the Vester-Ulbricht mecanism is feasible, and have shed some light on the origins of life on our planet.

These experiments are hard, but have been made easier with the use of a new tool called a rubidium spin-filter. This award support the development of this apparatus into a usable tool.  To make these experiments more relevant for the problem of biological homochirality, targets under investigation recently have been the biologically more relevant amino acids cysteine and cystine (Figure 4).  Using the spin filter we have now shown similar chiral effects in cysteine collisions with spin-polarized (chiral) electrons.

This award has also supported the development of fast chiral electron sources (Figure 5).  These are produced when a femtosecond pulsed laser emits electrons from a nanoscopic tip of the semiconductor GaAs (Figure 6).  The subsequent pulses of electrons have a very short (< 10-13 s) duration, meaning that they can, in principle, be used to study chiral processes on the short femtosecond time scales associated with chemical reactions.

This award has had significant broader impacts. In terms of human resource development, it has supported one Postdoctoral Research Associate, 5 graduate students, 7 undergraduates, and 1 high school student. (Another undergraute student was supported by the NSF in  a REU Program run by the University of Nebraska.) Perhaps the broadest outreach of this award was the result of work it supported to study the physics of yet annother chiral system: the tight spiral pass in American football. Before this work, no one had clearly explained why such a pass "turns over" in flight (Figure 1). That is to say, why is it caught pointing down when it was thrown pointing up? The answer is closely related to the fast spin, and hence chirality, of the ball. There are also analogies with its behavior and that of a rapidly spinning top. This work was published in a physics journal, but was also reported in full-length articles in the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal.
